Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
Scheduled admit for cycle 2 of ICE
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of follicular 

lymphoma stage IIIA s/p CHOP x 6 in ___ followed by CVP and 
then rituximab x 6 in ___, now with transformed DLBCL who 
presents with for cycle 2 of ICE therapy. Per report, she has 
significant  neck and upper thoracic involvement, as well as 
mesenteric  involvement.  She underwent her first cycle of ICE 
without complications ___ and since then has been getting 
rituxan and neupogen. 

On arrival to the floor, patient is feeling well.  Her only 
complaint from her previous session of chemo was mild stomach 
upset.  She denies any fevers/chills, headache, vision changes, 
sore throat, SOB, CP, abd pain, N/V/D, dysuria or new rashes.

 
Past Medical History:
Follicular lymphoma stage IIA with disease recurrence
- ___ developed worsening musculoskeletal back pain, early 
satiety, hypoalbuminemia and found to have mesenteric mass
- ?___ ex lap with 15 cm lobulated mass involving the 
duodenum, retroperitoneum and celiac access.  Biopsies showed 
Follicular lymphomas grade II/III.  Reportedly negative staging 
Gallium scan. CD10+ BCL2+
- ___ completed 6 cycles CHOP, complications included 
SVC/innominate thrombus (tPA)
- ___ CT showed persistent 7 x 3.5 x 9 cm oblong mass, bone
marrow at completion was negative for lymphomatous involvement.
- ___ PET-CT with very slight amount of increased tracer
activity within the posterior left supraclavicular region. No
other areas of FDG avid disease were noted 
- ___ through ___ per records she was treated with CVP
followed by course of single agent Rituxan
- ___ through ___ surveillance imaging with no evidence of
recurrent disease, stable mesenteric mass.
- ___ abdominal pain led to CT with no change in mass size,
increased conspicuity of nodular borders
- ___ PET-CT with L. hilar LN PET-avid to SUV 7.9, otherwise
stable mesenteric mass with low level SUV 2.2 stable since 
prior.
- ___ CT torso showed persistent mesenteric and left hilar
lymphadenopathy. Stable right middle lobe small focus of ground
glass opacity and adjacent subpleural fat hypertrophy, 
suggestive
of inflammatory process. Stable right adnexal cyst.  
- ___ Presented to PCP ___ ___iscomfort. 
Exam
revealed new adenopathy. Labs notable for LDH 341, WBC 10.1,
normal differential, PLT 452. 
- ___ PET CT revealed, "Large left cervical,
supraclavicular, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and small mesenteric 
lymphadenopathy, all of which is markedly FDG-avid and 
concerning for
lymphoma." SUVmax 35.5.
- ___iopsy revealed diffuse large B cell
lymphoma, CD20+ CD10+ lambda restricted. MIB and cytogenetics 
are pending
- ___ C1D1 ICE

PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY:  
Cerebral Aneurysm s/p coil ___ c/b hyperthesia of R V1/V2 
(*Known slight CN VI palsy & mild proptosis of R eye)
Hypogammaglobulinemia, 
Mild GERD
OA / LBP
Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth
Trochanteric Bursitis
s/p Excisional Bx L Cervical Lymph Node
s/p L total knee replacement ___
s/p I&D Labial Abscess
s/p Excision Cyst R ___ Digit of Hand

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
VS: T 98.3, HR 92, BP 124/78, R 20, 97%RA
General: well-appearing but elderly lady, reclined in bed, NAD
HEENT: Normocephalic, R eye ptosis, 1mm vesicle on posterior 
soft palate(chronic per patient), otherwise OP is clear
Neck: 3cm x 1cm L anterior LN, no thyromegaly   
CV: RRR, no r/g/m 
Lungs: CTA b/l
Abdomen: Soft, NT, ND, +BS
Ext: WWP, ___ edema L > R, chronic venous stasis changes noted 
on b/l shins    
Neuro: Notable for R CN VI palsy & diminished sensation in CN 
V-1, also sluggish R CN III response to direct & indirect 
illumination, otherwise CN's grossly intact, intact muscle 
strength all extremities, intact light sensation b/l ___
Skin: R pheresis line c/d/i

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
VS: T 98.6, HR 95, BP 114/76, R 20, 97%RA
General: well-appearing but elderly lady, reclined in bed, NAD
HEENT: Normocephalic, R eye ptosis, 1mm vesicle on posterior 
soft palate(chronic per patient), otherwise OP is clear
Neck: 3cm x 1cm L anterior LN, no thyromegaly   
CV: RRR, no r/g/m 
Lungs: CTA b/l
Abdomen: Soft, NT, ND, +BS
Ext: WWP, ___ edema L > R, chronic venous stasis changes noted 
on b/l shins    
Neuro: Notable for R CN VI palsy & diminished sensation in CN 
V-1, also sluggish R CN III response to direct & indirect 
illumination, otherwise CN's grossly intact, intact muscle 
strength all extremities, intact light sensation b/l ___
Skin: R pheresis line c/d/i

 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
---------------
___ 10:00AM   WBC-5.7 RBC-3.14* HGB-9.8* HCT-28.4* MCV-90 
MCH-31.3 MCHC-34.7 RDW-14.4
___ 10:00AM   NEUTS-72.1* LYMPHS-17.1* MONOS-10.1 EOS-0.2 
BASOS-0.5
___ 10:00AM   PLT COUNT-232#
___ 10:00AM   ___ PTT-29.3 ___
___ 10:00AM   UREA N-11 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-141 POTASSIUM-4.4 
CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-15
___ 10:00AM   ALT(SGPT)-17 AST(SGOT)-23 LD(LDH)-311* ALK 
PHOS-108* TOT BILI-0.2
___ 10:00AM   ALBUMIN-3.9 CALCIUM-8.6 PHOSPHATE-3.2 
MAGNESIUM-2.1
___ 01:00PM URINE  BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.0 
LEUK-NEG
___ 01:00PM URINE  COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___

DISCHARGE LABS:
---------------
___ 05:00AM BLOOD WBC-4.8 RBC-3.06* Hgb-9.6* Hct-28.5* 
MCV-93 MCH-31.3 MCHC-33.6 RDW-15.5 Plt ___
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Neuts-78.2* Lymphs-16.9* Monos-4.5 
Eos-0.1 Baso-0.4
___ 05:00AM BLOOD ___ 05:00AM BLOOD Glucose-125* UreaN-14 Creat-0.7 Na-142 
K-4.1 Cl-107 HCO3-26 AnGap-13
___ 05:00AM BLOOD ALT-15 AST-14 LD(LDH)-246 AlkPhos-102 
TotBili-0.1
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.3 UricAcd-3.2
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of follicular 
lymphoma stage IIIA s/p CHOP x 6 in ___ followed by CVP and 
then rituximab x 6 in ___, now with transformed DLBCL who 
presents with for cycle 2 of ICE therapy

# DLBCL: Here for c2 of R-ICE.  c1 R-ICE started ___ and 
completed without complications. She will need Neupogen D5-12 to 
support ___.  Will continue bactrim, acyclovir and allopurinol 
for ppx.  Plan for PET-CT after ___ cycle to assess disease 
response to therapy.  

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#H/o LLE edema and cellulitis: the pt reports chronic b/l lower 
extremity edema s/p L TKR in ___ U/S was negative for DVT 
on her most recent admission. She also has chronioc venous 
stasis and a h/o of MRSA infections (boils, abdominal and 
labial) and on her most recent admission was treated empirically 
with amoxicillin and bactrim. Currently without signs of 
infections and ___ edema at her baseline.

# Migraines: Takes coffee + indomethacin at home. She received 1 
dose of fioricet for headache during her hospitalization with 
relief of her symptoms.  

# h/o SVC syndrome s/p thrombectomy. Currently no clinical 
evidence SVC thrombus.  She received heparin SC as her platelets 
remained >50 during her hospitalization.

# HLD: continued home statin.

# Mood: continued home venlafaxine. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Ondansetron 8 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 
2. Gabapentin 900 mg PO BID 
3. Allopurinol ___ mg PO DAILY 
4. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 
5. Pravastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 
6. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
7. Acyclovir 400 mg PO Q8H 
8. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
9. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
10. Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID 
11. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim SS 1 TAB PO DAILY 
12. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
13. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acyclovir 400 mg PO Q8H 
2. Allopurinol ___ mg PO DAILY 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
4. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
5. Gabapentin 900 mg PO BID 
6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
7. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
8. Ondansetron 8 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 
9. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
10. Pravastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 
11. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 
12. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim SS 1 TAB PO DAILY 
13. Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Diffuse Large B cell lymphoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
                             ___ MD ___
 
Completed by: ___

response to therapy.

History of Present Illness:
___ female with transformed diffuse large B cell lymphoma 
presents today for cycle 3 of R-ICE.  She was initially 
diagnosed with follicular lymphoma in ___, and relapsed in ___ 
with a transformation to DLBCL. She will collect her stem cells 
for autologous transplant after this cycle. Her workup is 
complete. The plan is for XRT after auto, as she has a residual 
avid area in her abdominal mass. Today, she reports improving 
neck pain, for which she has been using occasional valium, soft 
collar, and warmth. It started last week. Otherwise, no HA, 
neuro changes, n/v/d, fevers chills.
 
Past Medical History:
Follicular lymphoma stage IIA with disease recurrence
- ___ developed worsening musculoskeletal back pain, early 
satiety, hypoalbuminemia and found to have mesenteric mass
- ?___ ex lap with 15 cm lobulated mass involving the 
duodenum, retroperitoneum and celiac access.  Biopsies showed 
Follicular lymphomas grade II/III.  Reportedly negative staging 
Gallium scan. CD10+ BCL2+
- ___ completed 6 cycles CHOP, complications included 
SVC/innominate thrombus (tPA)
- ___ CT showed persistent 7 x 3.5 x 9 cm oblong mass, bone
marrow at completion was negative for lymphomatous involvement.
- ___ PET-CT with very slight amount of increased tracer
activity within the posterior left supraclavicular region. No
other areas of FDG avid disease were noted 
- ___ through ___ per records she was treated with CVP
followed by course of single agent Rituxan
- ___ through ___ surveillance imaging with no evidence of
recurrent disease, stable mesenteric mass.
- ___ abdominal pain led to CT with no change in mass size,
increased conspicuity of nodular borders
- ___ PET-CT with L. hilar LN PET-avid to SUV 7.9, otherwise
stable mesenteric mass with low level SUV 2.2 stable since 
prior.
- ___ CT torso showed persistent mesenteric and left hilar
lymphadenopathy. Stable right middle lobe small focus of ground
glass opacity and adjacent subpleural fat hypertrophy, 
suggestive
of inflammatory process. Stable right adnexal cyst.  
- ___ Presented to PCP ___ ___iscomfort. 
Exam
revealed new adenopathy. Labs notable for LDH 341, WBC 10.1,
normal differential, PLT 452. 
- ___ PET CT revealed, "Large left cervical,
supraclavicular, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and small mesenteric 
lymphadenopathy, all of which is markedly FDG-avid and 
concerning for
lymphoma." SUVmax 35.5.
- ___iopsy revealed diffuse large B cell
lymphoma, CD20+ CD10+ lambda restricted. MIB and cytogenetics 
are pending
- ___ C1D1 ICE

PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY:  
Cerebral Aneurysm s/p coil ___ c/b hyperthesia of R V1/V2 
(*Known slight CN VI palsy & mild proptosis of R eye)
Hypogammaglobulinemia, 
Mild GERD
OA / LBP
Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth
Trochanteric Bursitis
s/p Excisional Bx L Cervical Lymph Node
s/p L total knee replacement ___
s/p I&D Labial Abscess
s/p Excision Cyst R ___ Digit of Hand

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
General: WDWN female, NAD, A&Ox4. Ptosis noted R, ansicoria L>R
(known).
HEENT: oropharynx no lesions
Neck: neck limited extention, rotation to R. No meningsmus. No
adenopathy throughout   
CV:  RRR no m/r/g
Lungs: CTA
Abdomen: soft NT -HSM
Ext:  no edema 
Neuro: as above
Access: R chest IJ c/d/i

MCV-96 MCH-31.4 MCHC-32.5 RDW-20.6* Plt ___
___ 12:35AM BLOOD WBC-4.0 RBC-2.45* Hgb-7.9* Hct-23.5* 
MCV-96 MCH-32.1* MCHC-33.6 RDW-20.1* Plt ___

MCV-98 MCH-30.6 MCHC-31.4 RDW-20.7* Plt ___

Baso-0

Eos-0.3 Baso-0

Eos-0.5 Baso-0
___ 12:00AM BLOOD Glucose-132* UreaN-13 Creat-0.6 Na-141 
K-3.6 Cl-105 HCO3-24 AnGap-16
___ 12:35AM BLOOD Glucose-156* UreaN-14 Creat-0.7 Na-140 
K-4.1 Cl-106 HCO3-24 AnGap-14
___ 12:10AM BLOOD Glucose-184* UreaN-14 Creat-0.7 Na-139 
K-4.3 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-14
___ 12:00AM BLOOD ALT-12 AST-14 LD(LDH)-189 AlkPhos-71 
TotBili-0.2
___ 12:35AM BLOOD ALT-11 AST-12 LD(___)-206 AlkPhos-77 
TotBili-0.2

TotBili-0.___LBCL transformed from follicular lymphoma: Ms. ___ was 
admitted for cycle 3 of R-ICE with goal of collection with this 
cycle, for which she has a right chest tunnelled line. Tolerated 
the chemo, except for some nausea and poor appetite, which were 
treated with anti-emetics. She will start her G-CSF upon 
discharge. She was started on Ciprofloxacin prophylaxis in 
anticipation of HSCT. She remains on Bactrim for PJP 
prophylaxis. She will f/u in ___ clinic regarding 
collection of her cells and schedule her transplant.
.
# history of coiled aneuyrsm and TIA: Her Aspirin was continued, 
but she was advised to stop on ___ since her platelets are 
expected to drop later this week. Her statin was held during 
chemo, which was resumed upon discharge.
.
# Torticolis, neck pain: Continued home regimen with Valium PRN, 
heat, and soft collar. She denied neck pain/stiffness at the 
time of discharge.
.
# Migraine: She had migrainous headaches during admission, which 
resolved on their own.
.
# Volume overload: She experienced mild volume overload and 
weight gain during her chemo course, which responded to a Lasix 
bolus x1. Her discharge weight was 245.0 lbs. She was advised to 
take oral Lasix PRN at home or to call clinic, if she notices 
increased swelling.
.
# Access: Right chest double-lumen tunneled line. There were 
intermittently problems with drawing blood and flushes, which 
appeared to be positional in nature. This was successfully 
managed with tPA. Pheresis team evaluated abilty to use line, 
and felt it should be adequate for collection despite positional 
nature. Patient was advised to call clinic if she has any 
further issues with the line.
.
All other chronic issues stable.

11. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim SS 1 TAB PO DAILY 
12. Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID 
13. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY

3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY - through ___

5. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
7. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 
8. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim SS 1 TAB PO DAILY 
9. Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID

11. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
12. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
13. Pravastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 
14. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lymphoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
.
It was a pleasure to meet you at the ___ 
___. You were admitted to receive chemotherapy both 
to treat your lymphoma and to mobilize your stem cells, which 
you sucessfully completed while with us. 
.
You will inject yourself with neupogen, following the calendar 
that ___ gives you. These injections may cause bone pain, 
take oxycodone should you experience this.  As prior, do not 
drive.
.
Continue all of your home medications as prior. We have added

taking Aspirin on ___ because we expect your 
platelets to start dropping later this week.
.
Thank you again for allowing us to participate in your care!
.

7. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 
8. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim SS 1 TAB PO DAILY 
9. Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID 
10. Ondansetron 8 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 
11. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
12. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
13. Pravastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 
14. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lymphoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
.
It was a pleasure to meet you at the ___ 
___. You were admitted to receive chemotherapy both 
to treat your lymphoma and to mobilize your stem cells, which 
you sucessfully completed while with us. 
.
You will inject yourself with neupogen, following the calendar 
that ___ gives you. These injections may cause bone pain, 
take oxycodone should you experience this.  As prior, do not 
drive.
.
Continue all of your home medications as prior. We have added 
cipro to prevent infection while you collect. You should stop 
taking Aspirin on ___ because we expect your 
platelets to start dropping later this week.
.
Thank you again for allowing us to participate in your care!
.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ with transformed DLBCL and h/o follicular lymphoma 
presenting for a scheduled autoSCT. She was also reporting an 
area of right medial thigh erythema, tenderness and induration 
to the transplant nurse over the phone on ___. She had a 
scheduled outpatient appointment for pre-transplant lab work. 
She had ___ at the outpatient heme/onc office which showed an 
acute right popliteal/ femoral DVT. 

Stem cell collection period prolonged as counts slower to 
recover than in the past.  Required addition of Mozibil with 
much improved stem cells collections with total yield of over 5 
x 10(e)6 CD 3 cells/kg.  Her last PET CT showed almost a 
complete response with residual focus of avidity in the bed of 
the abdominal mass.  She was evaluated by radiation oncology 
with the plan for consolidative radiation therapy to be done 
following her autologous transplant.  Echocardiogram on 
___ showed normal left ventricular wall thickness and 
cavity size with mildly depressed global systolic function with 
LVEF of 45%.  PFT's from ___ showed FVC of 66%, FEV1 of 
73%, TLC of 73% and DLCO of 93%.  Bone marrow aspirate and 
biopsy on ___ showed no evidence for lymphoma but was 
noted for a small mature lymphocyte clone that is a separate 
malignancy of
the CLL phenotype.  She has no indication of this in her blood. 
As her transformed lymphoma needs to be treated and is more life
threatening if left untreated, the decision was made to proceed
with the autologous transplant as planned.
 
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY:  
Transformed DLBCL with a history of follicular lymphoma stage 
IIA 
- ___ developed worsening musculoskeletal back pain, early
satiety, hypoalbuminemia and found to have mesenteric mass
- ?___ ex lap with 15 cm lobulated mass involving the
duodenum, retroperitoneum and celiac access. Biopsies showed
Follicular lymphomas grade II/III. Reportedly negative staging
Gallium scan. CD10+ BCL2+
- ___ completed 6 cycles CHOP, complications included
SVC/innominate thrombus (tPA)
- ___ CT showed persistent 7 x 3.5 x 9 cm oblong mass, bone
marrow at completion was negative for lymphomatous involvement.
- ___ PET-CT with very slight amount of increased tracer
activity within the posterior left supraclavicular region. No
other areas of FDG avid disease were noted 
- ___ through ___ per records she was treated with CVP
followed by course of single agent Rituxan
- ___ through ___ surveillance imaging with no evidence of
recurrent disease, stable mesenteric mass.
- ___ abdominal pain led to CT with no change in mass size,
increased conspicuity of nodular borders
- ___ PET-CT with L. hilar LN PET-avid to SUV 7.9, otherwise
stable mesenteric mass with low level SUV 2.2 stable since 
prior.
- ___ CT torso showed persistent mesenteric and left hilar
lymphadenopathy. Stable right middle lobe small focus of ground
glass opacity and adjacent subpleural fat hypertrophy, 
suggestive
of inflammatory process. Stable right adnexal cyst. 
- ___ Presented to PCP ___ ___iscomfort. 
Exam revealed new 
adenopathy. Labs notable for LDH 341, WBC 10.1, normal 
differential, PLT 452.

supraclavicular, mediastinal
lymphadenopathy, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and small 
mesenteric
lymphadenopathy, all of which is markedly FDG-avid and 
concerning for
lymphoma." SUVmax 35.5.

lymphoma, CD20+

mass, SUV ___ C4 Rituximab
- PLANNED ___ C4 ICE followed by stem cell mobilization and 
collection

.
ACUTE ISSUES: 
.
#Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL): transformed from 
follicular lyphoma. Underwent BEAM conditioning followed by 
scheduled autoSCT on ___. Post-transplant course complicated by 
febrile neutropenia, for which she was on cefepime, vancomycin 
and micafungin (to cover inguinal skin wounds). Recieved 5U 
PRBCs and 5U platelets to maintain hct > 21 and plts > 10. She 
was on PCA for a period of time for mucositis. Neutropenia 
resolved on ___, at which point antibiotics and G-CSF were 
discontinued. Patient was able to advance diet slowly as 
mucositis resolved; by discharge she was taking excellent PO 
hydration and continuing to advance her diet. Sent home on 
acyclovir for fungal ppx, to start Bactrim SS for PCP ppx on 
___.  
.
#DVT: New, provoked. ___ in outpatient heme/onc office showed 
acute DVT in the right popliteal/femoral veins + superficial 
thrombosis. Secondary to malignancy. Given lovenox in the 
clinic. Pt reported to be tachycardic and dyspneic in clinic, 
c/f PE was high. CTA chest negative for PE. IVC filter placed on 
___ by ___. Heparin drip discontinued ___ given falling 
platelet count. Left lower extemity noted to be swollen more 
significantly than the right on ___, but dopplers showed only 
stable right leg clot. Thrombocytopenia resolved on ___, and 
she was started on warfarin as well as lovenox sc at 
prophylactic dose. On ___ she was switched to lovenox sc at 
treatment dose (100mg BID); will start on warfarin as outpatient 
at a later date, once diet and medications have stabilized.  
.
#Bilateral groin skin tears: skin tears in inguinal region 
beneath panus c/b intertrigo/fungal infection. Developed prior 
to onset of neutropneia, started on vancomycin and micafungin + 
topical fungal cream. Healed well with proper wound care. 
Micafungin and vancomycin discontinued once neutropenia 
resolved. 
.
CHRONIC ISSUES: 
.
# Back and L hip pain: has h/o L hip bursistis; no h/o sciatica. 
Description of pain c/w musculoskeletal source, no concerning 
physical exam findings. Symptoms fluctuated through course of 
stay based on patient positioning/activity level. 
.
#Migranes: Patient reporting unilateral (right sided) headache 
with photosensitivity and nausea on ___. Resolved on ___ 
after receiving fioracet and ativan for nausea. 
.
#Neuropathy: Stable, likely secondary to old sensory stroke. 
Also has new numbness on fingertips bilaterally likely secondary 
to etoposide. Continued home gabapentin.
.
#H/o cerebral aneurysm: Stable. Discovered ___ years ago on MRA 
head in right ICA cavernous sinus. S/p coiling ___ years ago. Has 
stable dysconjugate gaze/pupil asymmetry from the aneurysm.   
.
#Depression: Stable, continued on home venlafaxine.
.
TRANSTIONAL ISSUES: 
.
# ANTICOAGULATION: discharged on lovenox; will continue for at 
least 2 weeks while diet increases/she starts on bactrim, and 
then be transitioned to warfarin as outpatient. 
.
# PCP ___: to start ___ sent home w/script

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___. You came in for an auto-stem cell 
transplant (autSCT) for your Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma 
(DLBCL). Just prior to admission you were found to have a deep 
vein thrombosis (DVT), for which you were started on lovenox and 
had an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placed on ___. You 
recieved your autoSCT on ___. 

Your post-transplant course was complicated by fever, requiring 
antibiotics. These were discontinued without incident when your 
white blood cell counts had recovered. Lovenox was held when 
your platelet count fell during chemotherapy. Anticoagulation 
with lovenox was restarted on ___ when your platelet count had 
recovered. 

You will remain on viral prophylaxis with acyclovir for now, and 
start PCP prophylaxis with ___ on ___.

febrile neutropenia, for which she was on cefepime, vancomycin

PRBCs and 5U platelets to maintain hct > 21 and plts > 10. She 
was on PCA for a period of time for mucositis. Neutropenia 
resolved on ___, at which point antibiotics and G-CSF were 
discontinued. Patient was able to advance diet slowly as 
mucositis resolved; by discharge she was taking excellent PO 
hydration and continuing to advance her diet. Sent home on 
acyclovir for fungal ppx, to start Bactrim SS for PCP ppx on 
___.  
.

acute DVT in the right popliteal/femoral veins + superficial 
thrombosis. Secondary to malignancy. Given lovenox in the

c/f PE was high. CTA chest negative for PE. IVC filter placed on 
___ by ___. Heparin drip discontinued ___ given falling 
platelet count. Left lower extemity noted to be swollen more 
significantly than the right on ___, but dopplers showed only 
stable right leg clot. Thrombocytopenia resolved on ___, and 
she was started on warfarin as well as lovenox sc at 
prophylactic dose. On ___ she was switched to lovenox sc at 
treatment dose (100mg BID); will start on warfarin as outpatient 
at a later date, once diet and medications have stabilized.  
.
#Bilateral groin skin tears: skin tears in inguinal region 
beneath panus c/b intertrigo/fungal infection. Developed prior 
to onset of neutropneia, started on vancomycin and micafungin + 
topical fungal cream. Healed well with proper wound care. 
Micafungin and vancomycin discontinued once neutropenia 
resolved. 
.

.

.

.

ACUTE ISSUES: 
. #Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL): transformed from 
follicular lyphoma. Underwent BEAM conditioning followed by 
scheduled autoSCT on ___. Post-transplant course complicated by 
febrile neutropenia, for which she was on cefepime, vancomycin 
and micafungin (to cover inguinal skin wounds). Recieved 5U 
PRBCs and 5U platelets to maintain hct > 21 and plts > 10. She 
was on PCA for a period of time for mucositis. Neutropenia 
resolved on ___, at which point antibiotics and G-CSF were 
discontinued. Patient was able to advance diet slowly as 
mucositis resolved; by discharge she was taking excellent PO 
hydration and continuing to advance her diet. Sent home on 
acyclovir for fungal ppx, to start Bactrim SS for PCP ppx on 
___. . #DVT: New, provoked. ___ in outpatient heme/onc office showed 
acute DVT in the right popliteal/femoral veins + superficial 
thrombosis. Secondary to malignancy. Given lovenox in the 
clinic. Pt reported to be tachycardic and dyspneic in clinic, 
c/f PE was high. CTA chest negative for PE. IVC filter placed on 
___ by ___. Heparin drip discontinued ___ given falling 
platelet count. Left lower extemity noted to be swollen more 
significantly than the right on ___, but dopplers showed only 
stable right leg clot. Thrombocytopenia resolved on ___, and 
she was started on warfarin as well as lovenox sc at 
prophylactic dose. On ___ she was switched to lovenox sc at 
treatment dose (100mg BID); will start on warfarin as outpatient 
at a later date, once diet and medications have stabilized. . #Bilateral groin skin tears: skin tears in inguinal region 
beneath panus c/b intertrigo/fungal infection. Developed prior 
to onset of neutropneia, started on vancomycin and micafungin + 
topical fungal cream. Healed well with proper wound care. Micafungin and vancomycin discontinued once neutropenia 
resolved. .

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
scheduled autologous transplant with BEAM conditioning
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: IVC filter placed
___: auto-stem cell transplant

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with transformed DLBCL and h/o follicular lymphoma 
presenting for a scheduled autoSCT. She was also reporting an 
area of right medial thigh erythema, tenderness and induration 
to the transplant nurse over the phone on ___. She had a 
scheduled outpatient appointment for pre-transplant lab work. 
She had ___ at the outpatient heme/onc office which showed an 
acute right popliteal/ femoral DVT. 

Stem cell collection period prolonged as counts slower to 
recover than in the past.  Required addition of Mozibil with 
much improved stem cells collections with total yield of over 5 
x 10(e)6 CD 3 cells/kg.  Her last PET CT showed almost a 
complete response with residual focus of avidity in the bed of 
the abdominal mass.  She was evaluated by radiation oncology 
with the plan for consolidative radiation therapy to be done 
following her autologous transplant.  Echocardiogram on 
___ showed normal left ventricular wall thickness and 
cavity size with mildly depressed global systolic function with 
LVEF of 45%.  PFT's from ___ showed FVC of 66%, FEV1 of 
73%, TLC of 73% and DLCO of 93%.  Bone marrow aspirate and 
biopsy on ___ showed no evidence for lymphoma but was 
noted for a small mature lymphocyte clone that is a separate 
malignancy of
the CLL phenotype.  She has no indication of this in her blood. 
As her transformed lymphoma needs to be treated and is more life
threatening if left untreated, the decision was made to proceed
with the autologous transplant as planned.
 
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY:  
Transformed DLBCL with a history of follicular lymphoma stage 
IIA 
- ___ developed worsening musculoskeletal back pain, early
satiety, hypoalbuminemia and found to have mesenteric mass
- ?___ ex lap with 15 cm lobulated mass involving the
duodenum, retroperitoneum and celiac access. Biopsies showed
Follicular lymphomas grade II/III. Reportedly negative staging
Gallium scan. CD10+ BCL2+
- ___ completed 6 cycles CHOP, complications included
SVC/innominate thrombus (tPA)
- ___ CT showed persistent 7 x 3.5 x 9 cm oblong mass, bone
marrow at completion was negative for lymphomatous involvement.
- ___ PET-CT with very slight amount of increased tracer
activity within the posterior left supraclavicular region. No
other areas of FDG avid disease were noted 
- ___ through ___ per records she was treated with CVP
followed by course of single agent Rituxan
- ___ through ___ surveillance imaging with no evidence of
recurrent disease, stable mesenteric mass.
- ___ abdominal pain led to CT with no change in mass size,
increased conspicuity of nodular borders
- ___ PET-CT with L. hilar LN PET-avid to SUV 7.9, otherwise
stable mesenteric mass with low level SUV 2.2 stable since 
prior.
- ___ CT torso showed persistent mesenteric and left hilar
lymphadenopathy. Stable right middle lobe small focus of ground
glass opacity and adjacent subpleural fat hypertrophy, 
suggestive
of inflammatory process. Stable right adnexal cyst. 
- ___ Presented to PCP ___ ___iscomfort. 
Exam revealed new 
adenopathy. Labs notable for LDH 341, WBC 10.1, normal 
differential, PLT 452. 
- ___ PET CT revealed, "Large left cervical, 
supraclavicular, mediastinal
lymphadenopathy, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and small 
mesenteric
lymphadenopathy, all of which is markedly FDG-avid and 
concerning for
lymphoma." SUVmax 35.5.
- ___iopsy revealed diffuse large B cell 
lymphoma, CD20+ 
CD10+ lambda restricted. MIB and cytogenetics are pending
- ___ C1D1 ICE
- ___ C1 Rituximab, clincally improved adenopathy
- ___ C2 Rituximab, WBC 6.5, PLT 43
- ___ Admit for C2D1 ICE
- ___ C3 Rituximab
- ___ PET CT showed almost complete resolution of FDG avid 
disease with a 
residual focus of avidity in the bed of the former abdominal 
mass, SUV ___ C4 Rituximab
- PLANNED ___ C4 ICE followed by stem cell mobilization and 
collection

 
Past Medical History:
--Transformed DLBCL with history of follicular lymphoma as noted
above. 
--CLL, noted on BM biopsy on ___.
--Cerebral Aneurysm s/p coil ___ c/b hyperthesia of R V1/V2 
(*Known slight CN VI palsy & mild proptosis of R eye)
--Hypogammaglobulinemia 
--Mild GERD
--OA / LBP
--Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth
--Trochanteric Bursitis
--s/p Excisional Bx L Cervical Lymph Node
--s/p L total knee replacement ___, walks with cane
--s/p I&D Labial Abscess
--s/p Excision Cyst R ___ Digit of Hand

 
Social History:
___
Family History:

HEENT: Normocephalic. Sclerae anicteric. PERRL, EOMI, MMM, OP

.

---------------
___ 12:04AM BLOOD WBC-4.2 RBC-2.62* Hgb-8.1* Hct-25.7*

CHRONIC ISSUES: 
.
# Back and L hip pain: has h/o L hip bursistis; no h/o sciatica. 
Description of pain c/w musculoskeletal source, no concerning

.
#Migranes: Patient reporting unilateral (right sided) headache 
with photosensitivity and nausea on ___. Resolved on ___

.
#Neuropathy: Stable, likely secondary to old sensory stroke. 
Also has new numbness on fingertips bilaterally likely secondary

.

.

.

Home With Service

___

# Secondary: Febrile Neutropenia, Deep Venous Thrombosis, 
Depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___. You came in for an auto-stem cell 
transplant (autSCT) for your Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma 
(DLBCL). Just prior to admission you were found to have a deep 
vein thrombosis (DVT), for which you were started on lovenox and 
had an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placed on ___. You 
recieved your autoSCT on ___. 

Your post-transplant course was complicated by fever, requiring 
antibiotics. These were discontinued without incident when your 
white blood cell counts had recovered. Lovenox was held when 
your platelet count fell during chemotherapy. Anticoagulation 
with lovenox was restarted on ___ when your platelet count had 
recovered. 

You will remain on viral prophylaxis with acyclovir for now, and 
start PCP prophylaxis with ___ on ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Transformed DLBCL with a history of follicular lymphoma stage 
IIA 
___: Transplant Date: 1

___: Graft: Auto

satiety, hypoalbuminemia and found to have mesenteric mass 
- ?___ ex lap with 15 cm lobulated mass involving the 
duodenum, retroperitoneum and celiac access. Biopsies showed 
Follicular lymphomas grade II/III. Reportedly negative staging 
Gallium scan. CD10+ BCL2+ 
- ___ completed 6 cycles CHOP, complications included 
SVC/innominate thrombus (tPA) 
- ___ CT showed persistent 7 x 3.5 x 9 cm oblong mass, bone 
marrow at completion was negative for lymphomatous involvement. - ___ PET-CT with very slight amount of increased tracer 
activity within the posterior left supraclavicular region. No 
other areas of FDG avid disease were noted 
- ___ through ___ per records she was treated with CVP 
followed by course of single agent Rituxan 
- ___ through ___ surveillance imaging with no evidence of 
recurrent disease, stable mesenteric mass. - ___ abdominal pain led to CT with no change in mass size, 
increased conspicuity of nodular borders 
- ___ PET-CT with L. hilar LN PET-avid to SUV 7.9, otherwise stable mesenteric mass with low level SUV 2.2 stable since 
prior. - ___ CT torso showed persistent mesenteric and left hilar 
lymphadenopathy. Stable right middle lobe small focus of ground 
glass opacity and adjacent subpleural fat hypertrophy, 
suggestive 
of inflammatory process. Stable right adnexal cyst. - ___ Presented to PCP ___ ___iscomfort. Exam 
revealed new adenopathy. Labs notable for LDH 341, WBC 10.1, 
normal differential, PLT 452. - ___ PET CT revealed, "Large left cervical, 
supraclavicular, mediastinal 
lymphadenopathy, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and small 
mesenteric 
lymphadenopathy, all of which is markedly FDG-avid and 
concerning 
for 
lymphoma." SUVmax 35.5. - ___iopsy revealed diffuse large B cell 
lymphoma, CD20+ CD10+ lambda restricted. MIB and cytogenetics 
are 
pending 
- ___ C1D1 ICE 
- ___ C1 Rituximab, clincally improved adenopathy 
- ___ C2 Rituximab, WBC 6.5, PLT 43 
- ___ Admit for C2D1 ICE 
- ___ C3 Rituximab 
- ___ PET CT showed almost complete resolution of FDG avid 
disease with a residual focus of avidity in the bed of the 
former 
abdominal mass, SUV 3 
- ___ C4 Rituximab 
- ___ C4 ICE followed by stem cell mobilization and 
collection, BMBx showed a nest of CLL unrelated to her 
aggressive 
lymphoma 
- ___ Presented with large DVTs, SVC filter placed 
- ___ D0 of a BEAM autoSCT, course notable for mucositis 
- ___ Switched to Rivaroxiban for AC 
- ___.

discharge.

will f/u with her outpatient providers.

first considering lumbar puncture. It was restarted on 
discharge.

CVID

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for high fevers, headache, and 
vomiting. We are not sure what caused your symptoms, but the 
most likely cause is IVIG-associated aseptic meningitis. Another 
cause may be a viral infection. We felt it was very unlikely you 
had a bacterial infection so we stopped your antibiotics. You 
continued to improve. Your fevers and headaches improved. Your 
vomiting was well-controlled on medications. And you were able 
to tolerate enough hydration by mouth and no longer needed IVs, 
so you were discharged home with plans to follow up with Dr. 
___ Dr. ___.

It was a pleasure to take care of you during your hospital stay,
Your ___ Team

___

# FEVER, HEADACHE, VOMITING: These symptoms occured within 12 
hours of finishing her last infusion of IVIG. Etiology is most 
likely aseptic meningitis as she also had neck stiffness and 
some mild photophobia. Her symptoms improved with supportive IV 
fluids, anti-emetics, and NSAIDs. At first she was started 
empirically on IV Vanc, IV cefepime, IV acyclovir, and Tamiflu 
to treat possible bacterial or HSV meningitis or influenza. 
Rapid flu screen was negative so Tamiflu was stopped. She had no 
encephalitis and was on ppx acyclovir prior to presentation, so 
suspicion of HSV meningoencephalitis was very low so IV 
acyclovir was stopped. Once ___ blood cultures were 
negative >24 hours, IV antibiotics were also stopped. The 
patient continued to improve and was afebrile > 24 hrs prior to 
discharge. 

# LYMPHOMA: s/p auto-stem cell transplant 44 days prior to 
admission. She was continued on ppx bactrim and acyclovir. She 
will f/u with her outpatient providers.

# H/o DVT: Rivaroxaban was held while inpatient since we were at 
first considering lumbar puncture. It was restarted on 
discharge.

vomiting. We are not sure what caused your symptoms, but the 
most likely cause is IVIG-associated aseptic meningitis. Another 
cause may be a viral infection. We felt it was very unlikely you 
had a bacterial infection so we stopped your antibiotics. You

after admission, she reported that her husband had fallen ill 
that day with similar symptoms. CT did not demonstrate colitis, 
but was performed without IV contrast. Ischemic colitis is

low residue diet and her home furosemide was temporarily held.

pending at the time of discharge. She was scheduled for clinic 
follow-up on ___.

# DLBCL- stage IIIb s/p autoSCT with BEAM conditioning, 
complicated by ___ pneumonitis. LDH 266. She has a restaging 
PET/CT scheduled for next week. She received pentamidine for PJP 
ppx on ___. She was maintained on acyclovir ppx as an 
inpatient. Although patient's symptoms are most likely from 
gastroenteritis and are currently improving, disease progression 
should be considered. She will obtain her outpatient PET/CT 
after discharge.

prednisone taper (5 mg weekly). She was continued on prednisone 
25 mg daily with plans to continue taper after discharge. Her 
next set of PFT's are already scheduled.

# Right ___ DVT- continued rivaroxaban.  Has IVC filter in place.

marrow/dilution effect from IVF. Reticulocyte count 4.6. WBC 
improving on ___ but platelets continuing to downtrend. She 
will need to f/u in clinic after discharge to ensure that her

Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with transformed DLBCL stage

# Emesis/diarrhea- history most consistent with viral 
gastroenteritis, with norovirus on differential. On the day 
after admission, she reported that her husband had fallen ill 
that day with similar symptoms. CT did not demonstrate colitis, 
but was performed without IV contrast. Ischemic colitis is 
unlikely given no cardiovascular risk factors. Other ddx include 
gastritis, pancreatitis, and hepatitis, but given her clinical 
presentation, these are less likely. Received 1L maintenance 
fluids overnight on ___. She still had some diarrhea and 
abdominal pain on ___ but her symptoms had greatly improved by 
___ and she was tolerating po's well. She was maintained on a 
low residue diet and her home furosemide was temporarily held. 
C. diff returned negative and other stool cultures/pcr were 
pending at the time of discharge. She was scheduled for clinic 
follow-up on ___.

# DLBCL- stage IIIb s/p autoSCT with BEAM conditioning, 
complicated by ___ pneumonitis. LDH 266. She has a restaging 
PET/CT scheduled for next week. She received pentamidine for PJP 
ppx on ___. She was maintained on acyclovir ppx as an 
inpatient. Although patient's symptoms are most likely from 
gastroenteritis and are currently improving, disease progression 
should be considered. She will obtain her outpatient PET/CT 
after discharge.

level/consider IVIG infusion if symptoms worsened, but the 
patient improved with IV/po fluids.

prednisone taper (5 mg weekly). She was continued on prednisone 
25 mg daily with plans to continue taper after discharge. Her 
next set of PFT's are already scheduled.

# Right ___ DVT- continued rivaroxaban.  Has IVC filter in place.

# Pancytopenia- Possibly viral suppression of bone 
marrow/dilution effect from IVF. Reticulocyte count 4.6. WBC 
improving on ___ but platelets continuing to downtrend. She 
will need to f/u in clinic after discharge to ensure that her 
counts and platelets are recovering.

# Hyperthesia of R V1/V2- chronic, occurred after coiling 
procedure for cerebral aneurysm. Continued home gabapentin.

# GERD- continued home omeprazole

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received xarelto for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1 (started at 10 mg uptitrated to her home dose of 20 mg 
daily).  The foley was removed on POD2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The overlying surgical 
dressing was changed on POD#2 and the Silverlon dressing was 
found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs 
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted 
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating 
a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with 
stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and 
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. 
 
Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Xarelto 20 mg daily to 
help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If you were 
taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to continue at 
your previous dose while taking this medication.  Wear ___ 
stockings for 6 weeks. 
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Silverlon dressing clean and 
dry. REMOVE on ___. It is okay to shower five days after 
surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision 
until after your four (4) week checkup. You may place a dry 
sterile dressing on the wound after the Silverlon dressing is 
removed, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly 
for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by at your follow-up visit in 3 weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

1. Acyclovir 400 mg PO Q8H 
2. Ascorbic Acid ___ mg PO DAILY 
3. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY 
4. FoLIC Acid 4 mg PO DAILY 
5. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. Gabapentin 600 mg PO QID 
7. Rivaroxaban 20 mg PO DAILY 
8. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO 3X/WEEK (___) 
9. Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID 
10. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
11. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*1
12. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q3-6hrs Disp #*120 
Tablet Refills:*0
13. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 tablet by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*30 Capsule Refills:*1

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R knee osteoarthritis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Xarelto 20 mg daily to 
help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If you were 
taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to continue at 
your previous dose while taking this medication.  Wear ___ 
stockings for 6 weeks. 
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Silverlon dressing clean and 
dry. REMOVE on ___. It is okay to shower five days after 
surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision 
until after your four (4) week checkup. You may place a dry 
sterile dressing on the wound after the Silverlon dressing is 
removed, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly 
for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by at your follow-up visit in 3 weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
 

Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
Mobilize frequently 
Treatments Frequency:
daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice
TEDs
staple removal and replace with steri-strips POD17 (___) 
remove silverlon on ___ (POD7) 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received xarelto for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1 (started at 10 mg uptitrated to her home dose of 20 mg 
daily).  The foley was removed on POD2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The overlying surgical 
dressing was changed on POD#2 and the Silverlon dressing was 
found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs 
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted 
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating 
a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with 
stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and 
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.

tolerated on the operative extremity.

procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received xarelto for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1 (started at 10 mg uptitrated to her home dose of 20 mg 
daily).  The foley was removed on POD2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The overlying surgical 
dressing was changed on POD#2 and the Silverlon dressing was 
found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs 
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted 
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating 
a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with

pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.

Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R knee osteoarthritis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Xarelto 20 mg daily to 
help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If you were 
taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to continue at 
your previous dose while taking this medication.  Wear ___ 
stockings for 6 weeks. 
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Silverlon dressing clean and 
dry. REMOVE on ___. It is okay to shower five days after 
surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision 
until after your four (4) week checkup. You may place a dry 
sterile dressing on the wound after the Silverlon dressing is 
removed, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly 
for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by at your follow-up visit in 3 weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
 

Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
Mobilize frequently

daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice

___

Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received xarelto for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1 (started at 10 mg uptitrated to her home dose of 20 mg 
daily).  The foley was removed on POD2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The overlying surgical 
dressing was changed on POD#2 and the Silverlon dressing was 
found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs 
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted 
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating 
a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with 
stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and 
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. 
 
Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Xarelto 20 mg daily to 
help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If you were 
taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to continue at 
your previous dose while taking this medication.  Wear ___ 
stockings for 6 weeks. 
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Silverlon dressing clean and 
dry. REMOVE on ___. It is okay to shower five days after 
surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision 
until after your four (4) week checkup. You may place a dry 
sterile dressing on the wound after the Silverlon dressing is 
removed, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly 
for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by at your follow-up visit in 3 weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

place.  Her dose of Xarelto had been decreased to 10 mg daily 
given her age and chronic history of DVT; she also had a lower

History of Present Illness:
A ___ year old female with a history of transformed follicular 
lymphoma s/p multiple past regimens as noted below, and

previous DVT and her circulation is poor.  She has had ongoing 
issues with sciatica with hip and left lower back pain, and has

At the end of ___ of ___, Ms. ___ noted 
increasing swelling of her right leg with shortness of breath.  
She had been on Xarelto for prior DVT and has an IVC filter in 
place.  Her dose of Xarelto had been decreased to 10 mg daily 
given her age and chronic history of DVT; she also had a lower

Because of the more acute drop in counts, Ms. ___ is being

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#Pancytopenia/Lymphoma disease status: Pancytopenic on 
admission. Counts remained stable while in house. BM Bx

developed with Dr. ___ likely involve administration 
of dacogen but this will be further delineated outpatient. 
Hemoglobin 7.1 on admission and patient received 1U prbcs prior 
to discharge.  

#Infection/URI: Presented w/ congestion and recent blood nasal 
exudates. On ___, was febrile. Respiratory viral, Blood, and 
Urine cx were obtained; CXR and CT sinus were evaluated. Vanc 
and cefepime were started. No infectious pathogen was identified 
and the patient had no further fevers. On ___, vancomycin was 
discontinued. On ___, cefepime was discontinued. She received 
symptomatic treatment with nasal saline and oxymetazoline. She 
was discharged with levaquin 500mg q24hrs (to complete a 7D 
course on ___ 

#LLE Wound: Wearing Unna boot on presentation which had been 
placed 5d PTA. Seen by wound c/s service. Daily dressing changes 
while in house. Lesion stable. Rash of chronic venous stasis, 
stable. Discharged with instructions to follow-up for usual care 
at ___.

#Anti-coagulation/DVT: Concern for RP Bleed on admission, ruled 
out by CT. Rivaroxaban held and patient treated with enoxaparin. 
The dose was held or modified at different times because of 
planned procedures. The patient did not have any acute bleeding 
events apart from bloody nasal exudate with nose blowing. On 
discharge, patient was restarted on home dose of Rivaroxaban 
(20mg PO daily). Platelets 85K at discharge 

#Back Pain: Improved with rest and oxycodone while patient was 
in hospital. Otherwise, continued gabapentin 900mg TID at 
discharge. No acute pain episodes prior to leaving.

symptoms. PRN inhalers ordered

after 4 hours and resolves with one or two episodes of vomiting.

appropriate given thrombocytopenia. No acute episodes prior to

Bone marrow biopsy by interventional radiology (___)

 
History of Present Illness:
A ___ year old female with a history of transformed follicular 
lymphoma s/p multiple past regimens as noted below, and 
ultimately an autoSCT with BEAM conditioning in ___.  She 
has comorbid CVID and receives IVIG monthly.  Her
post transplant course was complicated by ___ pneumonitis.  She 
underwent a total right knee replacement on ___.  Her 
postoperative course was complicated by foot drop likely due to 
irritation of her peroneal nerve from the CPM machine as well as 
a cellulitis of the right leg following her surgery which was 
treated with a course of Keflex.  This is the same leg as her 
previous DVT and her circulation is poor.  She has had ongoing 
issues with sciatica with hip and left lower back pain, and has 
had steroid injections.

At the end of ___ of ___, Ms. ___ noted 
increasing swelling of her right leg with shortness of breath.  
She had been on Xarelto for prior DVT and has an IVC filter in 
place.  Her dose of Xarelto had been decreased to 10 mg daily 
given her age and chronic history of DVT; she also had a lower 
platelet count for a period of time.  She was seen and admitted 
at ___ with ultrasound showing DVT of the right leg 
once again.  Chest CT with no PE or other adenopathy.  Abdomen 
and Pelvic CT without adenopathy or concern for lymphoma 
recurrence.  Xarelto was increased back to 20 mg daily. 

INTERVAL HISTORY:  Over the past 1 - 2 months, Ms. ___ was 
noted for a drop in her white count with neutropenia as well as 
a drop in her platelet count.  This had been noticed in the past 
with the plan to repeat a bone marrow biopsy but her counts 
returned to baseline so bone marrow biopsy was deferred.  She 
was also noted for a nonhealing wound on her left leg after hit 
on the shin several weeks ago.  She was treated with a course of 
Keflex with still poor healing.  Given 2 doses of Neupogen to 
support counts.  She was seen by the wound care clinic at ___ 
___ yesterday and the area was debrided and dressing 
applied.

At her visit today, Ms. ___ is noted for further drop in 
blood counts(platelet count is low but more her baseline).  She 
reports not feeling well towards the middle of last week and on 
___ morning, she developed increasing left lower back pain, 
radiating to the buttock area.  She feels this is related to her 
sciatica but is different pain pattern; no radiating pain down 
the leg as she usually has.  Pain increases with changing 
positions and with initial ambulation.  She walks with a cane.  
In addition, she developed increasing nasal congestion on 
___ night which seemed to come on suddenly.  No fevers, 
chills, night sweats, sore throat.  When blowing her nose, she 
noted increased blood with clots although no frank epistaxis.  

Because of the more acute drop in counts, Ms. ___ is being 
admitted for further evaluation for possible bleed given on 
anticoagulation vs evolving MDS-->Leukemia.

chemotherapy x 3 cycles. ___ autoBMT (BEAM). ___ XRT to 
local disease. She has a hx of hypogammaglobulinemia.

History of Present Illness:
A ___ year old female with a history of transformed follicular 
lymphoma s/p multiple past regimens as noted below, and 
ultimately an autoSCT with BEAM conditioning in ___.  She 
has comorbid CVID and receives IVIG monthly.  Her
post transplant course was complicated by ___ pneumonitis.  She 
underwent a total right knee replacement on ___.  Her 
postoperative course was complicated by foot drop likely due to 
irritation of her peroneal nerve from the CPM machine as well as 
a cellulitis of the right leg following her surgery which was 
treated with a course of Keflex.  This is the same leg as her 
previous DVT and her circulation is poor.  She has had ongoing 
issues with sciatica with hip and left lower back pain, and has 
had steroid injections.

At the end of ___ of ___, Ms. ___ noted 
increasing swelling of her right leg with shortness of breath.  
She had been on Xarelto for prior DVT and has an IVC filter in 
place.  Her dose of Xarelto had been decreased to 10 mg daily 
given her age and chronic history of DVT; she also had a lower 
platelet count for a period of time.  She was seen and admitted 
at ___ with ultrasound showing DVT of the right leg 
once again.  Chest CT with no PE or other adenopathy.  Abdomen 
and Pelvic CT without adenopathy or concern for lymphoma 
recurrence.  Xarelto was increased back to 20 mg daily. 

INTERVAL HISTORY:  Over the past 1 - 2 months, Ms. ___ was 
noted for a drop in her white count with neutropenia as well as 
a drop in her platelet count.  This had been noticed in the past 
with the plan to repeat a bone marrow biopsy but her counts 
returned to baseline so bone marrow biopsy was deferred.  She 
was also noted for a nonhealing wound on her left leg after hit 
on the shin several weeks ago.  She was treated with a course of 
Keflex with still poor healing.  Given 2 doses of Neupogen to 
support counts.  She was seen by the wound care clinic at ___ 
___ yesterday and the area was debrided and dressing 
applied.

At her visit today, Ms. ___ is noted for further drop in 
blood counts(platelet count is low but more her baseline).  She 
reports not feeling well towards the middle of last week and on 
___ morning, she developed increasing left lower back pain, 
radiating to the buttock area.  She feels this is related to her 
sciatica but is different pain pattern; no radiating pain down 
the leg as she usually has.  Pain increases with changing 
positions and with initial ambulation.  She walks with a cane.  
In addition, she developed increasing nasal congestion on 
___ night which seemed to come on suddenly.  No fevers, 
chills, night sweats, sore throat.  When blowing her nose, she 
noted increased blood with clots although no frank epistaxis.  

Because of the more acute drop in counts, Ms. ___ is being 
admitted for further evaluation for possible bleed given on 
anticoagulation vs evolving MDS-->Leukemia.

MDS. ___ was started on decitabine as an outpatient and 
re-presented with fevers and neutropenia. She had an exhaustive 
workup of her fevers, including skin and psoas biopsies, and 
tissue uPCR was sent, but there was no culture positivity or 
positive findings in her infectious workup. However, after 
consultation with ID, it was decided to treat empirically for 
presumptive osteomyelitis/discitis with 6 weeks of vancomycin 
(750mg IV q12h), cefepime (2g IV q12h), micafungin (100 mg PO 
q24h). Micafungin was chosen instead of posaconazole due to 
___ differences; but she did receive posaconazole while 
inpatient. Simultaneously, the patient was having significantly 
worsened back pain after her MDS diagnosing bone marrow biopsy. 
She was started on opioid pain control, which was uptitrated and 
augmented with Valium to good effect. She went home with BID 
oxycontin, PRN oxycodone, and QHS Valium. She will follow-up as 
outpatient with Dr. ___.

# Fever + neutropenia: The patient received 2 doses of 
decitabine as outpatient prior to experiencing first fever of 
101 at home, then 100.4 in clinic during third dose decitabine 
administration. She was admitted for fever in setting of 
cytoreduction, and she eventually became truly neutropenic. An 
exhaustive workup was performed, centering on MRI findings of 
potential osteomyelitis/discitis with potential L psoas 
invovlvement. This tissue was biopsied, negative by culture, and 
uPCR pending at the time of discharge. The patient will be given 
empiric therapy of vancomycin/cefepime/micafungin for a total of 
6 weeks (___) and instructed to have 1 month follow-up 
spinal imaging. A LLE wound was also biopsied and grew nothing. 
By exclusion, decitabine is thought to be the likely culprit of 
the fever.

# left gluteal furuncle: Formed at the marked site of the ___ L 
psoas biopsy. By ultrasound found to only have subcutaneous 
edema without fluid collection. This will be followed by patient 
and outpatient team as potential new nidus of infection if 
appearing worse or causing pain.

# low back pain: Acute on chronic in this patient, who has 
baseline degenerative changes. She also had R iliac crest bone 
marrow biopsy prior to this admission which may have caused 
hematoma, inflammatory, or direct nerve injury which contributed 
to her severe pain. She was uptitrated to a pain regimen 
including standing Oxycontin BID, oxycodone PRN, and Valium QHS, 
which she was able to tolerate with good effect. She worked with 
___ and was deemed fit for discharge home with services.

# treatment related MDS: Secondary to autoSCT with BEAM 
conditioning for DLBCL. Patient had bone marrow biopsy which 
diagnosed new-onset treatment related MDS, but may have also 
caused severe acute-on-chronic back pain for which she is 
receiving opioids and benzodiazapines. Will receive Bactrim for 
PCP prophylaxis starting at discharge.

# history of DVT: History of LLE DVTs, on Rivaroxaban at home 
and IVC filter in place. Rivaroxaban was held once Plt<75k in 
setting of multi-line decline from decitabine.

# common variable immunodeficiency: Patient had multiple IgG 
checks for known CVID and did not require IVIG as inpatient.

through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of

disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after

administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.
