mental status and symptoms were back to her baseline. Urine 
culture drawn in the ED (taken in bed-pan, not sterile) grew 
Enteroccus faecium pan-resistant, including ampicillin and 
vancomycin. The organism was not sensitive to any of the 
antibiotics that she was on, thus the organism was not treated, 
however she improved to baseline as above. Thus the UTI was 
likely not the source of her AMS. In this light, she was not 
sent out on further antibiotics, but was counseled to return to 
the hospital if she developed urinary symptoms or more 
confusion. The true etiology is unclear. It may have been a 
viral infection or possibly cerebral hypoperfusion in the 
setting of vascular pathology (h/o aneurysms). 

#UTI: see above for urine culture growing Enterococcus faecium. 

#LLE edema: Had a history of DVTs and was previously on 
rivaroxaban but this had been held for some time ___ 
thrombocytopenia. She has an IVC filter in place. Rivaroxaban 
was not restarted ___ thrombocytopenia. Held on discharge. 

#?Nocardia skin rash: Had area of tenderness at site chronic 
venous stasis dermatitis, previously biopsied by not sent for 
AFB/nocardia. When patient had AMS, nocardia was thought to be 
possible explanation with skin finding and AMS. Biopsy was 
deferred in-house since patient resolved to baseline. Consider 
biopsy if symptoms return. 

#Neutropenia: Started on PO cipro and fluconazole once IV abx 
were discharged as above. Discharged on cipro and fluc. qTC on 
discharge was 431ms. 

TRANISTION ISSUES
=================
[]acyclovir not seen as a previous home med, was started on 
acyclovir for ppx on discharge 
[]discharged on PO fluconazole and cipro ongoing for ppx
[]consider biopsy of L medial shin and sending for AFB/nocardia

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were confused and we were 
concerned for infection. 

What happened in the hospital:
- You had scans of your brain that did not show bleeding or 
infection
- You had an MRI of your spine that did not show evidence of 
bone infection, also called osteomyelitis
- We added an antibiotic in the hospital to your home regimen of 
IV antibiotics 
- Your confusion cleared and you returned to your baseline 
- We found a bacteria in your urine that was not treated by the 
antibiotics you were on. However, bacteria can normally be in 
the urine and we do not think this was the cause of your 
confusion or chills. IF YOU DO HAVE PAIN WITH URINATION OR 
INCREASED URINARY FREQUENCY, OR IF YOU BECOME CONFUSED AGAIN, 
COME BACK TO THE HOSPITAL AND CALL YOUR DOCTOR.

- Attend your follow-up appointments 
- Take your medications as prescribed 
- Take your new medications, ciprofloxacin, acyclovir, and 
fluconazole (to prevent infections), until otherwise instructed 
by your oncologist

It was a pleasure taking care of you. 

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team

History of Present Illness:
___ year old female with history of transformed diffuse large B 
cell lymphoma s/p a curative attempt with an autoSCT with BEAM 
conditioning in ___ ___s IFRT with course complicated 
by BCNU pneumonitis, who was subsequently found to have
treatment-related MDS on BM biopsy performed on ___. She is
currently on C2D12 of treatment with decitabine and presents 
with
one day of confusion, round to have rigors in the ED. Of note, patient was recently admitted to ___ service from
___ to ___ after starting her first cycle of decitabine for
persistent neutropenic fever, with no clear source identified. She had negative cultures. Imaging with MRI revealed possible
early discitis and possible myositis of the psoas muscle. She
underwent psoas muscle biopsy and also had an ulcer on the L 
shin
which was biopsied. Culture and infectious studies were all
negative. In addition, a universal PCR was sent which was
negative. Infectious Disease team consulted. She was treated
ultimately with 6week course of vancomycin/Cefepime/Micafungin
(last day previously planned for ___ with empiric coverage
for osteomyelitis. She was seen yesterday in ___ clinic for
follow-up on ___ where she reported feeling well and was noted 
to
be _______alert and oriented. In ER, endorses vomiting, anxiety and confusion. Does not feel
feverish and denies CP, SOB. She was noted to be AO-3 in ER. CTH
showed no acute intracranial process. CXR showed moderate
cardiomegaly (unchanged) and mild Pulm vasc congestion. She was treated with Vancomycin, cefepime and Micafungin and was
admitted to ___ service. On floor, patient seen in distress from headaches and nausea. Headache, "not very severe, not ___ , more of a moderate pain"
present on only R side of the head, unlike her previous migraine
attacks. Denies neck stiffness, able to touch chin to chest
without issues. No sick contacts. No fevers or rash suggestive 
of
meningococcal infection. She is nauseous and is seen moving
around in be trying to find a comfortable position. She is able to provide good history but some slowing in her
thought process seen, unsure if she is distracted from the pain
and nausea but she stops sentences midway and needs prompting to
finish her sentences. She is AO-3. Clear thought content. Goal
directed behavior. Able to express herself well albeit above
symptoms. Temp yesterday per pt was 97 but she felt chills. No other
documented high fevers. Review of Systems:  
(+) Per HPI. Positive for fevers and chill. Positive for Nausea. Negative for
neck stiffness, night sweats, headache, vision changes,
rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath,
chest pain, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation,
BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.

___.

lamina at this

inflammatory

the T2

endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis.

the spinal

noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar 
spine and to 
the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at 
L2-3.  This 
includes a low signal of the vertebral endplates on the T1 
weighted images and 
high signal of these endplates on the STIR images.  This finding 
has not 
changed since ___. 
  
New since ___ but unchanged since ___ are 
similar changes 
at the L4-5 interspace.  There is low signal of the endplates on 
the T1 
weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal imaging was performed with T2, T1, and STIR 
technique, 
followed by axial T2 imaging. This was followed by sagittal and 
axial T1 
images obtained after the uneventful intravenous administration 
of 11 mL of 
Gadavist  contrast agent. 
  
COMPARISON:  Lumbar spine MR examinations ___ and ___.  
CT abdomen and pelvis ___. 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar 
spine and to 
the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at 
L2-3.  This 
includes a low signal of the vertebral endplates on the T1 
weighted images and 
high signal of these endplates on the STIR images.  This finding 
has not 
changed since ___. 
  
New since ___ but unchanged since ___ are 
similar changes 
at the L4-5 interspace.  There is low signal of the endplates on 
the T1 
weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

Discharge Instructions:

concerned for infection.

FINDINGS:  
  
Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar 
spine and to 
the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at 
L2-3.  This 
includes a low signal of the vertebral endplates on the T1 
weighted images and 
high signal of these endplates on the STIR images.  This finding 
has not 
changed since ___. 
  
New since ___ but unchanged since ___ are 
similar changes 
at the L4-5 interspace.  There is low signal of the endplates on 
the T1 
weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

___.

inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection.

the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be

unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.

noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the

There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1

This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal imaging was performed with T2, T1, and STIR 
technique, 
followed by axial T2 imaging. This was followed by sagittal and

images obtained after the uneventful intravenous administration

Gadavist  contrast agent. 
  
COMPARISON:  Lumbar spine MR examinations ___ and ___.  
CT abdomen and pelvis ___. 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar 
spine and to 
the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at 
L2-3.  This 
includes a low signal of the vertebral endplates on the T1 
weighted images and 
high signal of these endplates on the STIR images.  This finding 
has not 
changed since ___. 
  
New since ___ but unchanged since ___ are 
similar changes 
at the L4-5 interspace.  There is low signal of the endplates on 
the T1 
weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were confused and we were 
concerned for infection. 

What happened in the hospital:
- You had scans of your brain that did not show bleeding or 
infection
- You had an MRI of your spine that did not show evidence of 
bone infection, also called osteomyelitis
- We added an antibiotic in the hospital to your home regimen of 
IV antibiotics 
- Your confusion cleared and you returned to your baseline 
- We found a bacteria in your urine that was not treated by the 
antibiotics you were on. However, bacteria can normally be in 
the urine and we do not think this was the cause of your 
confusion or chills. IF YOU DO HAVE PAIN WITH URINATION OR 
INCREASED URINARY FREQUENCY, OR IF YOU BECOME CONFUSED AGAIN, 
COME BACK TO THE HOSPITAL AND CALL YOUR DOCTOR.

- Attend your follow-up appointments 
- Take your medications as prescribed

fluconazole (to prevent infections), until otherwise instructed 
by your oncologist

It was a pleasure taking care of you. 

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team

Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___

demonstrate fatty

weighted

the lower L4

muscle, if so, it

Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on

change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

#Altered mental status: Presented with word finding difficulty 
and generalized malaise with decreased PO intake, without true 
global sensorium deficit. 1 month prior during hospitalization 
had been diagnosed with presumed osteomyelitis though imaging 
was equivocal, and started on 1 month broad spectrum ABX course.

mental status and symptoms were back to her baseline. Urine 
culture drawn in the ED (taken in bed-pan, not sterile) grew 
Enteroccus faecium pan-resistant, including ampicillin and 
vancomycin. The organism was not sensitive to any of the 
antibiotics that she was on, thus the organism was not treated, 
however she improved to baseline as above. Thus the UTI was

sent out on further antibiotics, but was counseled to return to

lamina at this

the T2

endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be

unlikely in the setting of discitis.

the spinal

At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.

intervertebral disc

vertebral body.

appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve

fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1

At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

documents.text:
FINDINGS:  
  
There is no evidence of acute infarction, or intracranial 
hemorrhage. The 
ventricles are normal in size without mass effect or midline 
shift. There is 
no abnormal enhancement, enhancing mass, or leptomeningeal 
disease. There is 
minimal nonspecific scattered foci of hyperintense T2/FLAIR 
signal changes 
within the subcortical and periventricular white matter, which 
is likely a 
sequela of chronic small vessel microangiopathy. The dural 
venous sinuses 
appear patent on post-contrast MPRAGE images. The paranasal 
sinuses appear 
clear. The bilateral mastoid air cells appear unremarkable. The orbits and 
visualized soft tissues appear unremarkable.

level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal imaging was performed with T2, T1, and STIR 
technique, 
followed by axial T2 imaging. This was followed by sagittal and 
axial T1 
images obtained after the uneventful intravenous administration 
of 11 mL of 
Gadavist  contrast agent. 
  
COMPARISON:  Lumbar spine MR examinations ___ and ___.  
CT abdomen and pelvis ___. 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar 
spine and to 
the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at 
L2-3.  This 
includes a low signal of the vertebral endplates on the T1 
weighted images and 
high signal of these endplates on the STIR images.  This finding 
has not 
changed since ___. 
  
New since ___ but unchanged since ___ are 
similar changes 
at the L4-5 interspace.  There is low signal of the endplates on 
the T1 
weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

#Altered mental status: Presented with word finding difficulty

On this admission, ___ c/f meningitis, cefepime was increased to

mental status and symptoms were back to her baseline. Urine 
culture drawn in the ED (taken in bed-pan, not sterile) grew 
Enteroccus faecium pan-resistant, including ampicillin and 
vancomycin. The organism was not sensitive to any of the 
antibiotics that she was on, thus the organism was not treated, 
however she improved to baseline as above. Thus the UTI was 
likely not the source of her AMS. In this light, she was not 
sent out on further antibiotics, but was counseled to return to 
the hospital if she developed urinary symptoms or more 
confusion. The true etiology is unclear. It may have been a 
viral infection or possibly cerebral hypoperfusion in the 
setting of vascular pathology (h/o aneurysms).

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were confused and we were 
concerned for infection. 

What happened in the hospital:
- You had scans of your brain that did not show bleeding or 
infection
- You had an MRI of your spine that did not show evidence of 
bone infection, also called osteomyelitis
- We added an antibiotic in the hospital to your home regimen of 
IV antibiotics 
- Your confusion cleared and you returned to your baseline 
- We found a bacteria in your urine that was not treated by the 
antibiotics you were on. However, bacteria can normally be in 
the urine and we do not think this was the cause of your 
confusion or chills. IF YOU DO HAVE PAIN WITH URINATION OR 
INCREASED URINARY FREQUENCY, OR IF YOU BECOME CONFUSED AGAIN,

fluconazole (to prevent infections), until otherwise instructed 
by your oncologist

It was a pleasure taking care of you. 

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team

to

of

 She is able to provide good history but some slowing in her

and nausea but she stops sentences midway and needs prompting to

 Temp yesterday per pt was 97 but she felt chills. No other

CT abdomen and pelvis ___. 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar 
spine and to 
the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at 
L2-3.  This 
includes a low signal of the vertebral endplates on the T1 
weighted images and 
high signal of these endplates on the STIR images.  This finding 
has not 
changed since ___. 
  
New since ___ but unchanged since ___ are 
similar changes 
at the L4-5 interspace.  There is low signal of the endplates on 
the T1 
weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum 
phenomenon in the 
intervertebral disc. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the 
scoliosis.  Much 
of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after 
contrast 
administration involves the left side of the superior portion of 
the L5 
vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of 
infection.  Note that 
this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently 
demonstrated a 
vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

22.  Venlafaxine 25 mg PO BID  
23. HELD- Rivaroxaban 20 mg PO DAILY  This medication was held. 
Do not restart Rivaroxaban until checking with your oncologist 
or PCP, as your platelets are too low to take this now

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: 
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
MDS
___ encephalopathy 
___ 

Secondary:
History of cerebrovascular accident
Chronic venous stasis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were confused and we were 
concerned for infection. 

What happened in the hospital:
- You had scans of your brain that did not show bleeding or 
infection
- You had an MRI of your spine that did not show evidence of 
bone infection, also called osteomyelitis
- We added an antibiotic in the hospital to your home regimen of 
IV antibiotics 
- Your confusion cleared and you returned to your baseline 
- We found a bacteria in your urine that was not treated by the 
antibiotics you were on. However, bacteria can normally be in 
the urine and we do not think this was the cause of your 
confusion or chills. IF YOU DO HAVE PAIN WITH URINATION OR 
INCREASED URINARY FREQUENCY, OR IF YOU BECOME CONFUSED AGAIN, 
COME BACK TO THE HOSPITAL AND CALL YOUR DOCTOR. 

After you leave the hospital: 
- Attend your follow-up appointments 
- Take your medications as prescribed 
- Take your new medications, ciprofloxacin, acyclovir, and 
fluconazole (to prevent infections), until otherwise instructed 
by your oncologist

It was a pleasure taking care of you. 

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team

___

study.  The CT

___.

the T2

endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis.

the spinal

intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.

appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal.

encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

mica were continued. On ___ ___ the patient rapidly improved and 
mental status and symptoms were back to her baseline. Urine 
culture drawn in the ED (taken in bed-pan, not sterile) grew 
Enteroccus faecium pan-resistant, including ampicillin and 
vancomycin. The organism was not sensitive to any of the 
antibiotics that she was on, thus the organism was not treated, 
however she improved to baseline as above. Thus the UTI was 
likely not the source of her AMS. In this light, she was not 
sent out on further antibiotics, but was counseled to return to 
the hospital if she developed urinary symptoms or more 
confusion. The true etiology is unclear. It may have been a 
viral infection or possibly cerebral hypoperfusion in the 
setting of vascular pathology (h/o aneurysms).

cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were confused and we were 
concerned for infection. 

What happened in the hospital:
- You had scans of your brain that did not show bleeding or 
infection
- You had an MRI of your spine that did not show evidence of 
bone infection, also called osteomyelitis
- We added an antibiotic in the hospital to your home regimen of 
IV antibiotics 
- Your confusion cleared and you returned to your baseline 
- We found a bacteria in your urine that was not treated by the 
antibiotics you were on. However, bacteria can normally be in 
the urine and we do not think this was the cause of your 
confusion or chills. IF YOU DO HAVE PAIN WITH URINATION OR 
INCREASED URINARY FREQUENCY, OR IF YOU BECOME CONFUSED AGAIN, 
COME BACK TO THE HOSPITAL AND CALL YOUR DOCTOR. 

After you leave the hospital: 
- Attend your follow-up appointments 
- Take your medications as prescribed 
- Take your new medications, ciprofloxacin, acyclovir, and 
fluconazole (to prevent infections), until otherwise instructed 
by your oncologist

It was a pleasure taking care of you. 

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team

At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root

within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally

several nerve roots

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were confused and we were 
concerned for infection. 

What happened in the hospital:
- You had scans of your brain that did not show bleeding or 
infection
- You had an MRI of your spine that did not show evidence of 
bone infection, also called osteomyelitis
- We added an antibiotic in the hospital to your home regimen of 
IV antibiotics 
- Your confusion cleared and you returned to your baseline 
- We found a bacteria in your urine that was not treated by the 
antibiotics you were on. However, bacteria can normally be in 
the urine and we do not think this was the cause of your 
confusion or chills. IF YOU DO HAVE PAIN WITH URINATION OR 
INCREASED URINARY FREQUENCY, OR IF YOU BECOME CONFUSED AGAIN, 
COME BACK TO THE HOSPITAL AND CALL YOUR DOCTOR.

- Take your medications as prescribed 
- Take your new medications, ciprofloxacin, acyclovir, and 
fluconazole (to prevent infections), until otherwise instructed 
by your oncologist

It was a pleasure taking care of you. 

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team

Again seen is scoliosis convex to the left in the upper lumbar

the right in the lower lumbar spine.  Again seen is anterior

on S1.  Again seen is ___ type 1 signal intensity change at

has not

weighted images and high signal on the STIR images.  All of the 
lumbar discs 
are hypointense on the T2 weighted and STIR images as are the 
discs at the T9 
through T12 level.  These are further manifestations of 
degenerative disc 
disease.  The endplates at L2-3 and at L4-5 enhance after 
contrast 
administration.  This is typical ___ type 1 change.  The 
intervertebral 
discs themselves do not enhance after contrast administration. 
  
Again seen are hypointensities in the intervertebral discs at 
multiple levels. 
Correlation with the CT abdomen and pelvis of ___ 
demonstrates 
that at every level from L2 through S1 included a vacuum

There is no evidence of abnormal intraspinal 
contrast-enhancement. 
  
The psoas and spinal erector muscles are asymmetric and 
demonstrate fatty 
atrophy bilaterally. These changes are likely a result of the

of the hyperintensity seen on the pre and postcontrast axial T1 
weighted 
images through the medial portion of the left psoas muscle at 
the lower L4 
level is due to the fatty atrophy, rather than enhancement.  It 
is unclear 
whether there is any abnormal enhancement of the left psoas 
muscle, if so, it 
is minimal. 
  
Hypointensity on the T1 weighted images with enhancement after

administration involves the left side of the superior portion of

vertebral body and extends through the pedicle into the facet 
joint.  This 
correlates with mild hyperintensity in these regions on the STIR 
images.  
There is slight induration of the adjacent fat between the 
vertebral body and 
the psoas muscle, best seen on image 30 of series 7 with 
enhancement seen on 
image 30 of series 9.  These findings may represent further 
inflammatory 
change due to degenerative disease, or a local focus of

this appearance is quite similar to that of the ___ 
study.  The CT 
scans through the left facet joint at this level consistently

vacuum phenomenon, arguing strongly against infection of the 
joint.  There is 
no evidence of bone destruction on the CT scans, which would be 
highly unusual 
if there were chronic osteomyelitis extending as far back as 
___.  
There is similar mild enhancement posteriorly along the left 
lamina at this 
level.  Overall, these findings again are more likely due to 
inflammatory 
degenerative disease than infection. 
  
The combination of vacuum phenomenon, low signal of the disc on 
the T2 
weighted images, ___ type 1 signal intensity changes of the 
endplates and 
stability over time all argue in favor of degenerative disc 
disease as the 
cause of these changes.  This constellation of findings would be 
extremely 
unlikely in the setting of discitis. 
  
There is a mild bulge of the T11-12 disc with no encroachment on 
the spinal 
cord or neural foramina. 
  
At T12-L1 there is no encroachment on the cord or foramina.  
Incidentally 
noted is an apparent right renal cyst, better evaluated on the 
recent CT scan. 
There is a small midline and right-sided protrusion of the 
intervertebral disc 
that extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
vertebral body.  
This does not contact the nerve roots.  The neural foramina 
appear normal. 
  
At L1-2 there is a small midline and right-sided disc protrusion 
that 
encroaches on the thecal sac but does not contact the nerve 
roots.  This 
fragment extends superiorly along the posterior margin of the L1 
body.  The 
neural foramina appear normal. 
  
At L2-3, bulging of the disc and facet osteophytes produce 
encroachment on the 
traversing L3 nerve roots bilaterally.  There is narrowing of 
the right neural 
foramen due to facet osteophytes and intervertebral osteophytes. 

  
At L3-4, disc bulging and intervertebral osteophytes contact the 
traversing 
right L4 nerve root.  The neural foramina are moderately 
narrowed bilaterally. 
  
At L4-5, there is disc bulging but no evidence of nerve root 
compression 
within the spinal canal.  There are prominent facet osteophytes 
bilaterally 
the produce severe left and moderate right 
  
At L5-S1, there is elongation of the spinal canal due to the 
subluxation of L5 
on S1.  There are prominent facet osteophytes bilaterally.  The 
combination of 
these factors and loss of height of the intervertebral disc as 
well as disc 
bulging produces moderate -severe narrowing of the neural 
foramina 
bilaterally. 
  
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. As discussed above, the vertebral, intervertebral disc, facet 
and left 
psoas muscle findings are likely due to a combination of 
scoliosis and chronic 
degenerative disc disease, likely with inflammation on this 
basis. 
2. The minimal change over time, vacuum phenomenon in the 
intervertebral discs 
and facet joints, absence of bone destruction and pattern of 
signal intensity 
abnormalities argue against infection as the etiology. 
3. Degenerative disc disease produces mild encroachment on 
several nerve roots 
and more severe narrowing of the neural foramina at several 
levels.

sent out on further antibiotics, but was counseled to return to 
the hospital if she developed urinary symptoms or more 
confusion. The true etiology is unclear. It may have been a 
viral infection or possibly cerebral hypoperfusion in the

concerned for infection.

Note her recent admit ___ she was recently admitted with

difficulty
and nausea/vomiting. She had been seen by ID ___ with concern 
for

and fluc.

C2D22 dacogen. plan for dacogen ___ next at ___.  Mental

She reports feeling fairly well until ___ night when she 
began
developing extreme fatigue and generalized weakness. Also had 1x
episode where she suddenly had to urinate and was incontinent of
urine. This happened again yesterday. No dysuria. No back pain,
no headaches, visual changes, and no one extremity has been
particularly weak compared to the rest of her body ( endorses 
leg
weakness but in line with generalized body weakness). She also
has been vomiting when she tries to eat for the past 48 hrs and
has no appetite but denies any melena, diarrhea, abd pain, and
had regular formed BM today and continues passing gas. Is 
burping
more than usual however. NO chest pain, dyspnea, cough, sore
throat, runny nose, or rash. All other 10 point ROS neg.

Note her recent admit ___ she was recently admitted with

and nausea/vomiting. She had been seen by ID ___ with concern 
for

or explain her focal neurologic deficits, especially as she had

course of amp/amox. On discharge she was continued on ppx cipro
and fluc.

She was next and last seen by ___ on ___ at which point she was
C2D22 dacogen. plan for dacogen ___ next at ___.  Mental

She reports feeling fairly well until ___ night when she 
began
developing extreme fatigue and generalized weakness. Also had 1x
episode where she suddenly had to urinate and was incontinent of
urine. This happened again yesterday. No dysuria. No back pain,
no headaches, visual changes, and no one extremity has been
particularly weak compared to the rest of her body ( endorses 
leg
weakness but in line with generalized body weakness). She also

more than usual however. NO chest pain, dyspnea, cough, sore
throat, runny nose, or rash. All other 10 point ROS neg.

marrow at completion was negative for lymphomatous involvement.

activity within the posterior left supraclavicular region. No
other areas of FDG avid disease were noted

followed by course of single agent Rituxan

recurrent disease, stable mesenteric mass.

increased conspicuity of nodular borders

stable mesenteric mass with low level SUV 2.2 stable since 
prior.

lymphadenopathy. Stable right middle lobe small focus of ground
glass opacity and adjacent subpleural fat hypertrophy, 
suggestive
of inflammatory process. Stable right adnexal cyst.

revealed new adenopathy. Labs notable for LDH 341, WBC 10.1,

lymphadenopathy, and small mesenteric

pending

lymphoma

- ___ DLCO 96%, reduce prednisone to 50 mg PO daily
- ___ DLCO 111%, reduce prednisone to 30 mg PO daily
- ___ DLCO 84%, pulse steroids, increase prednisone to 50 
mg
PO daily. PLT 81, Bactrim switched to Dapsone for PCP ___.

due to hemolysis.
- ___ Decreased prednisone to 5 mg PO daily. Noro virus
persistently positive.

Unchanged mesenteric fullness.

10
mg

by foot drop likely d/t irritation of peroneal nerve and
cellulitis.

dilatation of the main pulmonary artery suggests worsening
pulmonary arterial hypertension of indeterminate etiology.

dilation of pulmonary artery.  Evaluated by Dr. ___
