IMAGING
=======
___ CT SINUS:
1. New bilateral maxillary sinus disease with hyperdense 
material suggesting fungal colonization or inspissated 
secretions.  However, there is also fat stranding in the retro 
maxillary fat pads, which raises the possibility of invasive 
fungal sinusitis in the context of immune suppression. 
2. Please see separate head CT for intracranial findings.

___ CT HEAD:
No acute intracranial abnormalities are identified or change 
seen compared with ___.

___ TTE:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is mildly 
enlarged. There is no evidence for an atrial septal defect by 
2D/color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ 
mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
a normal cavity size. There is normal regional and global left 
ventricular systolic function. Quantitative biplane left 
ventricular ejection fraction is 56 % (normal 54-73%). Left 
ventricular cardiac index is normal (>2.5 L/min/m2). There is no 
resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. No ventricular 
septal defect is seen. Normal right ventricular cavity size with 
normal free wall motion. Tricuspid annular plane systolic 
excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The aortic sinus diameter is normal 
for gender with a mildly dilated ascending aorta. The aortic 
arch diameter is normal with a normal descending aorta diameter. 
The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal. There 
is no aortic valve stenosis. There is no aortic regurgitation. 
The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened with no mitral 
valve prolapse. There is mild [1+] mitral regurgitation. The 
pulmonic valve leaflets are normal. The tricuspid valve leaflets 
appear structurally normal. There is mild [1+] tricuspid 
regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure 
is normal. There is a trivial pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: 
Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and regional/ global biventricular systolic function. Mild 
mitral regurgitation. Mildly dilated ascending aorta.

___ CT chest without contrast
No evidence of recurrent lymphoma in the chest. Stable small 
mediastinal lymph nodes. Complete resolution of the parenchymal 
opacity in the right lower lobe which most likely represented 
pneumonia.  Patchy opacity in the left lung base is new and 
could represent atelectasis. 

___ MRI skull base with and without contrast
1. Limited study as described.
2. Interval progression of opacification and enhancement within 
the left mastoid air cells and middle ear cavity concerning for 
otomastoiditis, with no definite evidence of intracranial 
extension.
3. Adjacent heterogeneity of the petrous temporal bone versus 
artifact.  If not artifactual, differential considerations 
include infectious and inflammatory etiologies.
4. Bilateral maxillary sinus disease is redemonstrated, 
aerosolized secretions are better demonstrated on the CT from ___, with no definite extension into the adjacent soft 
tissue.
5. Question mild enhancement of the left retro maxillary fat 
versus volume averaging of adjacent vessels.  Recommend 
attention on follow-up imaging.
6. Nonspecific new clivus and medial temporal bone marrow 
heterogeneity compared to ___ prior exam with question 
enhancement.  While finding may represent marrow expansion, 
infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic etiologies are not 
excluded on the basis of this examination.  Recommend attention 
on follow-up imaging.

___ MR head with and without contrast
1. Unchanged persistent extensive fluid opacification and 
enhancement within the left middle ear cavity and mastoid air 
cells concerning for 
otomastoiditis.  No evidence of intracranial extension. 
2. Persistent heterogenous signal intensity within the adjacent 
petrous 
temporal bone.  Inflammatory, infectious or neoplastic 
etiologies are not 
excluded. 
3. Mild mucosal thickening in the frontal sinus, multiple 
ethmoid air cells and predominately in the bilateral maxillary 
sinuses, improved since the prior study.  Enhancement in the 
retromaxillary fat is difficult to evaluate due to lack of T1 
post-contrast fat saturated images. 
4. Persistent heterogenous signal intensity within the clivus, 
nonspecific. Differential considerations include marrow 
expansion, infectious, inflammatory or neoplastic etiologies. 
5. No evidence of hemorrhage, infarction, mass or other abnormal 
enhancement. 

___ bilateral lower extremity venous ultrasound
1. Nonocclusive deep vein thrombosis in the mid right femoral 
vein, new 
compared to ___. 
2. Deep vein thrombosis in the right popliteal vein.  Of note, 
the right 
popliteal vein contained a DVT on ultrasound ___, 
however the 
chronicity of the DVT seen today is uncertain. 
3. No evidence of DVT in the left lower extremity. 

___ MR head with and without contrast
1. Ongoing opacification and enhancement of the left mastoid air 
cells and 
middle ear cavity, concerning for otomastoiditis. 
2. There is no evidence of intracranial extension. 
3. No acute intracranial abnormality is identified. 
4. Persistent, unchanged heterogenous signal intensity within 
the clivus. This is nonspecific in nature. 

___ chest x-ray AP
Chronic deformity of the right rib cage.  Cardiomediastinal 
silhouette is 
within normal limits.  There are no focal consolidations, 
pleural effusion. Right basilar atelectasis.  Tortuous aorta.  
There are no pneumothoraces.

___ CT SINUS:
1. New bilateral maxillary sinus disease with hyperdense 
material suggesting fungal colonization or inspissated 
secretions.  However, there is also fat stranding in the retro 
maxillary fat pads, which raises the possibility of invasive 
fungal sinusitis in the context of immune suppression.

___ CT HEAD:
No acute intracranial abnormalities are identified or change 
seen compared with ___.

___ TTE:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is mildly 
enlarged. There is no evidence for an atrial septal defect by 
2D/color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ 
mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
a normal cavity size. There is normal regional and global left 
ventricular systolic function. Quantitative biplane left 
ventricular ejection fraction is 56 % (normal 54-73%). Left 
ventricular cardiac index is normal (>2.5 L/min/m2). There is no 
resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. No ventricular 
septal defect is seen. Normal right ventricular cavity size with 
normal free wall motion. Tricuspid annular plane systolic 
excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The aortic sinus diameter is normal 
for gender with a mildly dilated ascending aorta. The aortic 
arch diameter is normal with a normal descending aorta diameter. 
The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal. There 
is no aortic valve stenosis. There is no aortic regurgitation. 
The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened with no mitral 
valve prolapse. There is mild [1+] mitral regurgitation. The 
pulmonic valve leaflets are normal. The tricuspid valve leaflets 
appear structurally normal. There is mild [1+] tricuspid 
regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure 
is normal. There is a trivial pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: 
Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and regional/ global biventricular systolic function. Mild 
mitral regurgitation. Mildly dilated ascending aorta.

___ CT chest without contrast
No evidence of recurrent lymphoma in the chest. Stable small 
mediastinal lymph nodes. Complete resolution of the parenchymal 
opacity in the right lower lobe which most likely represented 
pneumonia.  Patchy opacity in the left lung base is new and 
could represent atelectasis. 

___ MRI skull base with and without contrast
1. Limited study as described.
2. Interval progression of opacification and enhancement within 
the left mastoid air cells and middle ear cavity concerning for 
otomastoiditis, with no definite evidence of intracranial 
extension.
3. Adjacent heterogeneity of the petrous temporal bone versus 
artifact.  If not artifactual, differential considerations 
include infectious and inflammatory etiologies.
4. Bilateral maxillary sinus disease is redemonstrated, 
aerosolized secretions are better demonstrated on the CT from ___, with no definite extension into the adjacent soft 
tissue.
5. Question mild enhancement of the left retro maxillary fat 
versus volume averaging of adjacent vessels.  Recommend 
attention on follow-up imaging.
6. Nonspecific new clivus and medial temporal bone marrow 
heterogeneity compared to ___ prior exam with question 
enhancement.  While finding may represent marrow expansion, 
infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic etiologies are not 
excluded on the basis of this examination.  Recommend attention 
on follow-up imaging.

___ MR head with and without contrast
1. Unchanged persistent extensive fluid opacification and 
enhancement within the left middle ear cavity and mastoid air 
cells concerning for 
otomastoiditis.  No evidence of intracranial extension. 
2. Persistent heterogenous signal intensity within the adjacent 
petrous 
temporal bone.  Inflammatory, infectious or neoplastic 
etiologies are not 
excluded. 
3. Mild mucosal thickening in the frontal sinus, multiple 
ethmoid air cells and predominately in the bilateral maxillary 
sinuses, improved since the prior study.  Enhancement in the 
retromaxillary fat is difficult to evaluate due to lack of T1 
post-contrast fat saturated images. 
4. Persistent heterogenous signal intensity within the clivus, 
nonspecific. Differential considerations include marrow 
expansion, infectious, inflammatory or neoplastic etiologies. 
5. No evidence of hemorrhage, infarction, mass or other abnormal 
enhancement. 

___ bilateral lower extremity venous ultrasound
1. Nonocclusive deep vein thrombosis in the mid right femoral 
vein, new 
compared to ___. 
2. Deep vein thrombosis in the right popliteal vein.  Of note, 
the right 
popliteal vein contained a DVT on ultrasound ___, 
however the 
chronicity of the DVT seen today is uncertain. 
3. No evidence of DVT in the left lower extremity. 

___ MR head with and without contrast
1. Ongoing opacification and enhancement of the left mastoid air 
cells and 
middle ear cavity, concerning for otomastoiditis. 
2. There is no evidence of intracranial extension. 
3. No acute intracranial abnormality is identified. 
4. Persistent, unchanged heterogenous signal intensity within 
the clivus. This is nonspecific in nature. 

___ chest x-ray AP
Chronic deformity of the right rib cage.  Cardiomediastinal 
silhouette is 
within normal limits.  There are no focal consolidations, 
pleural effusion. Right basilar atelectasis.  Tortuous aorta.

Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with history of follicular

complicated by therapy-related myelodysplasia treated with 
alloHSCT with Flu/Bu/ATG RIC (D0 ___ complicated by 
graft-versus-host disease, multiple deep vein thromboses with

(___) complicated by residual cranial nerve palsy who

venetoclax/decitabine.

# AML
# t-MDS ___ alloHSCT

host with significant co-morbidities. G6PD normal. Patient

biopsy. Chimerism from cytogenetics shows a greater percentage

put on different antifungals. BMB ___ with reassuring 
findings, no signs of disease. Neupogen given briefly with 
appropriate marrow response. Patient kept on acyclovir and 
atovaquone for prophylaxis. Bactrim chose over atovaquone at 
discharge.

facial warmth. CT SINUS (___) demonstrated pan-opacification of
bilateral maxillary sinuses with circumferential mucosal
thickening, with fat stranding in the retro maxillary fat pads
concerning for invasive fungal vs bacterial sinusitis yet

with heterogeneity in left maxilla/middle ear c/f infectious

findings, no signs of disease. Neupogen given briefly with

atovaquone for prophylaxis. Bactrim chose over atovaquone at 
discharge.

# Maxillary sinusitis
Presented with one week of progressive sinus pressure, headache,
facial warmth. CT SINUS (___) demonstrated pan-opacification of
bilateral maxillary sinuses with circumferential mucosal
thickening, with fat stranding in the retro maxillary fat pads

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
right labial abscess
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
IV antibiotics
Incision and Drainage of labial abscess

 
History of Present Illness:
___ P3 female with h/o non-Hodgkins lymphoma presents to
the ___ ED with a right labial abscess.  Patient initially
noticed a pimple on her right labium one week ago, with 
associated
labial itching.  Over the last three days it has been enlarging. 

She tried placing warm compresses over the area, with no
improvement.  

In the last day, the area has become increasing swollen,
erythematous, and painful.  It is now difficult to walk.  She
denies drainage from the area.  Denies fever or chills.  Denies
abdominal pain.  Denies excessive vaginal discharge.  

Patient has a history of a MRSA infection of an abdominal boil
___ years ago.  She denies h/o diabetes and states that recent
fasting blood sugar was 89.  Denies current immunosuppression,
her non-Hogkin's lymphoma has been in remission since ___
 
Past Medical History:
ObHx:
SVD x 3, no complications

GynHx:
Postmenopausal since age ___
s/p tubal ligation
denies h/o abnl paps
denies h/o STIs

PMH:
Cerebral aneurysm s/p multiple coil and stent procedures
h/o Non Hodgkins Lymphoma, remission since ___.
Migraines
Trigeminal neuralgia
Anterior outlet syndrome, s/p anterior scalenotomy
GERD 
OA
Carpal tunnel
MRSA positive boil on abdomen

PSH:
Ex-lap for right-sided pain, tubal ligation
Ex-lap for lymphoma
Ex-lap for ruptured Meckel's diverticulum
Anterior fusion C5-6
Anterior scalenotomy

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
PE: VS: T 99.4  BP 132/69  HR 100  RR 18  O2Sat 98% RA
NAD
Abd soft, obese, NT, cutaneous candidiasis in bilateral groin
folds
Right labium majorus 8cm x 5cm area of significant induration,
warm, extensive erythema (across entire right labium, mons, and
lower abdomen; from 4cm above pubic symphysis to buttocks), no
obvious area of fluctance, no drainage, no ulceration; no
Bartholin's cyst; moderately tender to palpation; no crepitus
Left labium normal appearing, soft, no erythema, no induration, 
no
drainage

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 02:10PM   WBC-14.6*# RBC-4.08* HGB-12.8 HCT-37.9 MCV-93 
MCH-31.2 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.1
HA1C: 6.0
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the surgical floor for IV antibiotics 
(Vancomycin/Unasyn) and pain control for treatment of labial 
cellulitis. There was concern for abscess despite ultrasound 
showing labial edema, without evidence of drainable fluid 
collection. She was afebrile for 24 hours but her pain and exam 
did not improve after 24 hours of IV antibiotics so a bedside 
incision and drainage was attempted. A fluid collection was 
identified and exlpored. It was found to have significant depth 
which was not ammendable to bedside drainage.  the patient was 
then taken to the OR for a complete incision and drainage. A 
large pocket of purulent fluid was drained, oculations were 
broken up, and a  Foley left in wound to drain the cavity. The 
drainage was sent for culture.
A blood culture that was drawn in the emergency room returned 
positive ___ bottles) for Coag negative Staph which was 
presumed to be a Staph epi contaminant. All further blood 
cultures were negative.
She was kept in the hospital for 48 hours more until the 
sensitivities returned from her would culture. She remained 
afebrile and her pain was significantly decreased after the 
procedure. 
The wound was found to be caused by MRSA but was sensitive to 
Bactrim. She was sent home on a 2 week course of Bactrim and 
will follow-up in 2 weeks in ___ clinic.
 
Medications on Admission:
Neurotin 300mg qam, 600mg qpm
Omeprazole 20mg qdaily
ASA 325mg qdaily
HCTZ 25mg BID
Etodolac 500mg BID
MVI

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain, fever.  
2. Ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain, fever.
Disp:*35 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
3. Gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q AM ().  
4. Gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: Three (3) Capsule PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
5. Etodolac 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO bid ().  
6. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. Venlafaxine 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
BID (2 times a day).  
9. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
10. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
11. Gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q AM ().  
12. Gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: Three (3) Capsule PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
13. Etodolac 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO bid ().  
14. Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day) for 14 days.
Disp:*28 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Labial cellulitis/abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, afebrile

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no 
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 
weeks. 
* You may eat a regular diet.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the surgical floor for IV antibiotics 
(Vancomycin/Unasyn) and pain control for treatment of labial 
cellulitis. There was concern for abscess despite ultrasound 
showing labial edema, without evidence of drainable fluid 
collection. She was afebrile for 24 hours but her pain and exam 
did not improve after 24 hours of IV antibiotics so a bedside 
incision and drainage was attempted. A fluid collection was 
identified and exlpored. It was found to have significant depth 
which was not ammendable to bedside drainage.  the patient was 
then taken to the OR for a complete incision and drainage. A 
large pocket of purulent fluid was drained, oculations were 
broken up, and a  Foley left in wound to drain the cavity. The 
drainage was sent for culture.
A blood culture that was drawn in the emergency room returned 
positive ___ bottles) for Coag negative Staph which was 
presumed to be a Staph epi contaminant. All further blood 
cultures were negative.
She was kept in the hospital for 48 hours more until the 
sensitivities returned from her would culture. She remained 
afebrile and her pain was significantly decreased after the 
procedure. 
The wound was found to be caused by MRSA but was sensitive to 
Bactrim. She was sent home on a 2 week course of Bactrim and 
will follow-up in 2 weeks in ___ clinic.

Labial cellulitis/abscess

* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

* Do not drive while taking narcotics.

douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 
weeks. 
* You may eat a regular diet.
